sen.j: 書院造（しょいんづくり）は、日本の室町時代中期以降に成立した住宅の様式である。
sen.e: Shoin-zukuri is one of Japanese residential architecture styles which were established after the middle of Muromachi Period.

sen.j: その後の日本の住宅は、広い意味で書院造の強い影響を受けている。
sen.e: Shoin-zukuri has made a strong influence on Japanese residential houses since then.

sen.j: 書院造は、床の間（または押板）、違い棚、付書院という座敷飾りを備えたものである。
sen.e: Shoin-zukuri is equipped with zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcove for the display of art objects) (or oshi-ita), chigai-dana (shelves built into the wall), and tsukeshoin (a built-in table).

A shoin (a study built in the shoin style) is furnished with zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcoves for the display of art objects) (or oshi-ita), chigai-dana (shelves built into the wall), and tsukeshoin (a built-in table).
sen.cmt: 「Shoin-zukuri is equipped」→「A shoin (a study built in the shoin style) is furnished with」, 「alcove」→「alcoves」. If more than one tsukeshoin may be present in the building it may be better to change to the plural 「built-in tables」
sen.e: A shoin (a study built in the shoin style) is furnished with zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcoves for the display of art objects) (or oshi-ita), chigai-dana (shelves built into the wall), and tsukeshoin (a built-in table).

sen.j: 今日の宴席でも、しばしば床の間の位置によって「上座」「下座」などと座席位置が決められることがあるが、これは床の間との位置関係が身分序列の確認を促す役割を果たしていたことを示していると言えよう。
sen.e: At a banquet today, seats are often designated as "kamiza" or "shimoza" according to the position of tokonoma, which implies that distances from tokonoma once helped members to remember ranks and orders of them.

Even at banquets today, seats are often designated as "kamiza" or "shimoza" according to their position relative to the tokonoma, which implies that distances from tokonoma once helped members to verify the rank and status of each other.

Even at banquets today, seats are often designated as 'kamiza' or 'shimoza' according to their position relative to the tokonoma, which implies that distances from tokonoma once helped members to verify each other's rank and status.

sen.j: 書院はもともと禅僧が書を読むために室内からはり出し、床板を書見のための机とし、前に明かり障子などを設けたものであった。
sen.e: Shoin was originally for Zen monks to read books with an elevated floor board as a desk extended out from the room and with akari-shoji in front to let light in.

sen.e: A shoin was originally for Zen monks to read books, with an elevated floor board as a desk extending out into the room and with akari-shoji in front to let light in.

sen.e: Oshi-ita (a shallow decorative alcove, a predecessor of the tokonoma) and chigai-dana were installed to display works of calligraphy, paintings and other ornaments.
